dialogue_line_replacements.text: De lunes a viernes. Los sábados, solo por la mañana.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Monday to Friday. Saturdays, mornings only.

dialogue_line_replacements.text: ¿Puedo pedir una cita para el martes?
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Can I request an appointment for Tuesday?

dialogue_line_replacements.text: Sí, ¿le va bien a las diez y media?
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Yes, does ten thirty suit you?

cultural_notes_overrides.formality: In Spain, lunch is 2–4pm and dinner 9–11pm — significantly later than English norms. Shops and businesses often close 2–5pm for the afternoon break. Medical appointments in the public system (Seguridad Social) may require advance booking.
cultural_notes_overrides.gestures: In Spain, time references often include 'a mediodía' (at noon/midday) as a common reference point. 'Por la tarde' in Spain typically means afternoon AND early evening.
cultural_notes_overrides.regional_variations: Spain uses the 24-hour clock more commonly in everyday speech than Latin America: 'Son las quince horas' (3pm) is normal in announcements. Days of the week are never capitalised in Spanish.
cultural_notes_overrides.distincion: Days with 'c' or 'z': 'lunes, martes, miércoles' — note 'miércoles' has no /θ/ issue, but 'diciembre' (December) features the Castilian /θ/: [diˈθjembɾe].
